question: What is the minimum width for a scaffold walkway?
ground_truth: According to OSHA standard 29 CFR 1926.451(b)(2), each scaffold platform and walkway must be at least 18 inches (46 centimeters) wide. If the working area is too restricted to allow this width, a narrower platform may be used only if guardrails or personal fall arrest systems are provided to ensure worker safety. All planks must be securely placed between the uprights and guardrails to provide full platform coverage and prevent gaps or tipping hazards.
ai_response:
According to OSHA standards outlined in **29 CFR 1926 Subpart L (Scaffolds)**, the minimum width for a scaffold walkway is **18 inches**. This requirement ensures safe passage for workers while reducing the risk of falls or other hazards.

### Relevant OSHA Standard:
- **29 CFR 1926.451(b)(2)** specifies: "Each scaffold platform and walkway shall be at least 18 inches wide unless otherwise specified or unless the scaffold is used only for access and not as a work platform."

Exceptions may apply in situations where narrower widths are necessary due to specific job site constraints, but these must be addressed with additional safety measures, such as guardrails or fall protection systems.

For further details, consult the referenced document pages, particularly **Page 66** and **Page 67**, which cover scaffold platform and walkway requirements.


**References:**
- [1169_USA_29-CFR-1926_OSHA_Eff-04-2017.pdf, Page 66](https://mtugenai.blob.core.windows.net/osha-safety-insight/1169_USA_29-CFR-1926_OSHA_Eff-04-2017.pdf?se=2026-11-05T17%3A28%3A07Z&sp=r&sv=2025-05-05&sr=b&sig=BiQQpWwFRWeS6v2Gn98qTH00c13Y6S3P3AxyS3z5cuo%3D)
- [1169_USA_29-CFR-1926_OSHA_Eff-04-2017.pdf, Page 72](https://mtugenai.blob.core.windows.net/osha-safety-insight/1169_USA_29-CFR-1926_OSHA_Eff-04-2017.pdf?se=2026-11-05T17%3A28%3A07Z&sp=r&sv=2025-05-05&sr=b&sig=BiQQpWwFRWeS6v2Gn98qTH00c13Y6S3P3AxyS3z5cuo%3D)
- [1169_USA_29-CFR-1926_OSHA_Eff-04-2017.pdf, Page 73](https://mtugenai.blob.core.windows.net/osha-safety-insight/1169_USA_29-CFR-1926_OSHA_Eff-04-2017.pdf?se=2026-11-05T17%3A28%3A07Z&sp=r&sv=2025-05-05&sr=b&sig=BiQQpWwFRWeS6v2Gn98qTH00c13Y6S3P3AxyS3z5cuo%3D)
- [1169_USA_29-CFR-1926_OSHA_Eff-04-2017.pdf, Page 67](https://mtugenai.blob.core.windows.net/osha-safety-insight/1169_USA_29-CFR-1926_OSHA_Eff-04-2017.pdf?se=2026-11-05T17%3A28%3A07Z&sp=r&sv=2025-05-05&sr=b&sig=BiQQpWwFRWeS6v2Gn98qTH00c13Y6S3P3AxyS3z5cuo%3D)
- [1169_USA_29-CFR-1926_OSHA_Eff-04-2017.pdf, Page 65](https://mtugenai.blob.core.windows.net/osha-safety-insight/1169_USA_29-CFR-1926_OSHA_Eff-04-2017.pdf?se=2026-11-05T17%3A28%3A07Z&sp=r&sv=2025-05-05&sr=b&sig=BiQQpWwFRWeS6v2Gn98qTH00c13Y6S3P3AxyS3z5cuo%3D)

question: What are the minimum illumination levels required in construction tunnels?
ground_truth: Per OSHA standard 29 CFR 1926.56, tunnels, shafts, and underground construction areas must be lighted to not less than 5 foot-candles during general operations. At tunnel headings or active work areas where drilling, mucking, or scaling is performed, illumination shall be increased to 10 foot-candles to provide safe visibility. Lighting equipment must be maintained in working condition and inspected regularly to ensure compliance with OSHA requirements for underground construction.
ai_response:
According to OSHA regulations, the minimum illumination levels required in construction tunnels are specified under **29 CFR 1926.56**. The standard outlines the following requirements:

- **5 foot-candles**: General tunnel areas, including shafts, during periods of active work.
- **10 foot-candles**: Where drilling, scaling, mucking, or other similar operations are being conducted.
- **3 foot-candles**: For tunnel areas not currently being worked on but accessible to workers.

These illumination levels are measured at the working surface and are intended to ensure worker safety by providing adequate visibility for tasks and navigation.

For further details, you can refer to **[29 CFR 1926.56 (up to date as of 3-10-2025).pdf, Page 1](https://mtugenai.blob.core.windows.net/osha-safety-insight/29%20CFR%201926.56%20(up%20to%20date%20as%20of%203-10-2025).pdf?se=2026-11-05T17%3A25%3A55Z&sp=r&sv=2025-05-05&sr=b&sig=Go5wzmzQvfJss21BPYdUD6TsLhpW4p48Bw/CGuJik7E%3D)**.


**References:**
- [29 CFR 1926.56 (up to date as of 3-10-2025).pdf, Page 1](https://mtugenai.blob.core.windows.net/osha-safety-insight/29%20CFR%201926.56%20(up%20to%20date%20as%20of%203-10-2025).pdf?se=2026-11-05T17%3A25%3A55Z&sp=r&sv=2025-05-05&sr=b&sig=Go5wzmzQvfJss21BPYdUD6TsLhpW4p48Bw/CGuJik7E%3D)

- [1169_USA_29-CFR-1926_OSHA_Eff-04-2017.pdf, Page 95](https://mtugenai.blob.core.windows.net/osha-safety-insight/1169_USA_29-CFR-1926_OSHA_Eff-04-2017.pdf?se=2026-11-05T17%3A28%3A07Z&sp=r&sv=2025-05-05&sr=b&sig=BiQQpWwFRWeS6v2Gn98qTH00c13Y6S3P3AxyS3z5cuo%3D)
